before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"7eqjf","text":"Cut paraffin sections at 4µm.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7gat","text":"Slides must be completely dry before deparaffinzation.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3d22n","text":"Bouin’s solution must be preheated to insure proper mordanting.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq6bu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"aucog","text":"The following protocol has been optimized for image analysis-based quantification of collagen within FFPE spheroid samples. It is run on a Leica ST5020 automated stainer. This protocol can be adapted to manual staining.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4epp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7l99j","text":"PURPOSE:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1d67l","text":"Trichrome stains are used to differentiate collagen from other tissues. They are usually nuclear and cytoplasmic stains, followed by differentiation, then followed by a collagen fiber stain. Trichrome stains are useful for indicating fibrotic changes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b72d2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6jpn","text":"PRINCIPLE:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cidf0","text":"The staining reaction is based on the differential effect of acid dye on collagen and other tissue components.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"brnjj","text":"Decreased red staining usually indicates that the staining solution has aged or been overused and should be discarded. If blue staining of connective tissue appears faded, the section has probably been overdifferentiated in the acetic acid solution.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9d3f","text":"Sections fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin will stain poorly and unevenly if not mordanted in either Bouin or a mercuric chloride solution; however, mercuric fixatives should not be used because of the toxicity.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: spheriod, microtissue, collagen, trichrome, FFPE, staining, quantitative, image analysis,autostainer, histology, Leica ST5020

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6argq","text":"For formalin fixed tissue, post-fix deparaffinized slides in Bouin’s solution for 1 hour at 56°C or at room temperature overnight. Do not leave in oven overnight. Bouin’s solution must be preheated to insure proper mordanting.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fi07","text":"Wash in water and discard first two changes to red container aqueous waste. Rinse in sink with running tap water for 5 - 10 minutes to remove the yellow color. Use warm water to remove excess yellow color.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1mrk","text":"Rinse in sink with distilled water for 30 seconds.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Masson Trichrome Protocol MT3B for Leica ST5020 Autostainer

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4na5k","text":"Use a resinous mounting medium to coverslip slides. Allow to dry flat for a minimum of 2 hours.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

title: Masson's Trichrome Staining Protocol for FFPE spheroids and microtissues

warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"7asb2","text":"Bouin's Fixative contains picric acid. Picric acid containing less than 10% water is very explosive; therefore, it is important that solutions not be spilled in the oven and then allowed to evaporate. For this reason, the staining jar containing Bouin's Fixative/picric acid should be placed inside a secondary container while in the oven.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
